choices.text: Inability to prove ovarian malignancy by histopathology before staging laparotomy
Inability to attain complete cytoreduction during surgery
Inability to start chemotherapy within 2 weeks of surgery
Need to perform resection anastomosis of bowel to achieve complete cytoreduction

questions.text: A patient presents to you with ovarian malignancy. Her CA 125 is 850 U/mL. Her MRI shows 15cm*15 cm ovarian mass along with omental caking. She is planned for staging laparotomy and adjuvant chemotherapy. Which of the following will have worst effect on the prognosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Inability to attain complete cytoreduction during surgery

  • Complete cytoreduction is the most important factor associated with survival in advanced ovarian cancers. Need for Resection anastomosis does not worsen prognosis

Other Options

  • Option A: Histopathological diagnosis is not required before staging laparotomy
  • Option B:  Overall survival has been founf to be less if time to chemotherapy was after 8 weeks following cytoreductive surgery
  • Option C: Need to perform resection anastomosis of bowel to achieve complete cytoreduction. An analysis of the retrospective data indicates that,  Intestinal resection does not appear to increase the overall morbidity caused by the operation. 

Educational Objective: 

Complete cytoreduction is the most important factor associated with survival in advanced ovarian cancers. Need for Resection anastomosis does not worsen prognosis

 

Ref: Berek & novak 16 edition, page 2589

choices.text: Call exner bodies are present
Highly chemosensitive
Level of Inhibin B is raised
Precocious puberty is due to associated adrenal tumors

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with precocious puberty and solid ovarian mass suspected to be granulosa cell tumor. Which of the following is false regarding these tumors:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Precocious puberty is due to associated adrenal tumors

 

  • Precocious purberty is due to secretion of estrogen by tumor as these tumors secrete estrogen. Hence these tumors commonly present as precociuos puberty or abnormal uterine bleeding

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Call Exner bodies are characteristically seen in Granulosa cell tumors on HPE

 

Option B: Highly chemosensitive: Granulosa cell tumors are highly chemosensitive. The chemotherapeutic regime of choice is the BEP regimen (Bleomycin, Etoposide, Cisplatin).

 

Option C: Level of Inhibin B is raised: Levels of Inhibin (A& B), Estradiol and AMH are raised in grabulosa cell tumor. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granulosa Cell Tumor of the Ovary: 

 

  • Granulosa cell tumors: 2 percent of all ovarian neoplasms.
  • Originates from the ‘rests’ of primitive granulosa cells unused in folliculogenesis.
  • It is the commonest ovarian stromal tumor.
  • It is bilateral in 2% 
  • The size varies, so also the consistency — may be solid or cystic.
  • Cut section: yellow or orange due to its lipid content.
  • Microscopic appearance: 
    • Coffee bean” nuclei. S
    • Call-Exner bodies: Pathognomonic of granulosa cell tumor.
  • The tumor cells secrete inhibin, estrogen and AMH (tumor markers)
  • As the tumor produces estrogen, there may be associated endometrial hyperplasia (50%) and unopposed estrogenic stimulation leads to development of endometrial carcinoma in about 5–10 percent of cases.
  • Clinical features: 
    • It occurs in all ages, 10 percent prior to puberty, 40 percent during childbearing period and 50 percent in postmenopausal women.
    • Prior to puberty: Precocious puberty
    • Childbearing period: Abnormal uterine bleeding
    • Postmenopausal: Bleeding
  • Treatment: Laparotomy and surgical staging followed by chemotherapy is done. Unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is the optimum treatment for children or women in the reproductive age.  BEP (Bleomycin, Etoposide and Cisplatin) is the chemotherapeutic regimens. It is a highly chemosensitive tumor.  Overall prognosis is good. Life time follow up is essential as recurrence can occur as late as 30 years

 

Ref: Berek & novak, 16 ed, page 2646

choices.text: Offer BRCA testing
Offer bilateral salpingooophorectomy
Offer CA 125 measurement
Offer bilateral mastectomy

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to you as she recently found out that her aunt passed away from breast cancer. Her mother had passed away from ovarian cancer 10 years of ago. What is the next best step:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Offer BRCA testing

 

This woman has 2 affected members, therefore the first step is testing for BRCA mutation, further management of salpingooophorectomy/mastectomy/ surveillance will depend on presence/absence of BRCA gene, her fertility and desire for further childbearing.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B: Offer bilateral salpingooophorectomy: This can be offered if BRCA is positive and once child bearing is complete

 

Option C: Offer CA 125 measurement: Ca 125 is to assess the risk of malignancy in a woman with an adnexal mass. Only after she has been diagnosed with ovarian cancer is the ca 125 helpful.

 

Option D: Offer bilateral mastectomy: In women with BRCA positive, b/l mastectomy can be offered. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

BRCA testing should be offered to women with: 

 

 

Ref: Berek and novak, 16 ed 2564

choices.text: Clinical history of passage of clear vesicles
Histological features showing hydropic changes in villi/ trophoblastic proliferation
Increased beta hCG levels
Ultrasound feature of snowstorm appearance

questions.text: A woman presents to emergency with amenorrhea, bleeding and passage of clear vesicles. She undergoes suction evacuation. The definitive diagnosis of molar pregnancy is made by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Histological features showing hydropic changes in villi/ trophoblastic proliferation

The definitive diagnosis of a molar pregnancy is made by histological examination.

  • HPE features consistent with the diagnosis of complete molar pregnancies include:
    • Absence of fetal tissue
    • Extensive hydropic change to the villi
    • Excess trophoblast proliferation.
  • HPE Features of a partial molar pregnancy include:
    • Presence of fetal tissue   
    • Focal hydropic change to the villi
    • Excess trophoblast proliferation

Ploidy status and immunohistochemistry staining for p57, a paternally imprinted gene, may help in distinguishing partial from complete molar pregnancies.

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Clinical history of passage of clear vesicles: Although this is highly suggestive of complete mole, confirmation is only on HPE
  • Option B: Increased beta hCG levels: Molar pregnancy is associated with very high bhCG levels but again is not conformatory of molar pregnancy
  • Option C: Snowstorm appearance on ultrasound: This is the classical picture on ultrasoud of complete mole but again is not conformatory of molar pregnancy

Educational Objective: 

  • HPE features consistent with the diagnosis of complete molar pregnancies include:
    • Absence of fetal tissue
    • Extensive hydropic change to the villi
    • Excess trophoblast proliferation. ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​
  • HPE Features of a partial molar pregnancy include:
    • Presence of fetal tissue   
    • Focal hydropic change to the villi
    • Excess trophoblast proliferation

Ref: Management of Gestational Trophoblastic Disease

Green-top Guideline No. 38 – June 2020

choices.text: Complete abortion
Complete mole
Incomplete abortion
Partial mole

questions.text: A 19-year-old primigravida presents to OPD with amenorrhea of 2.5 months, positive urine pregnancy test and bleeding per vagina. Her ultrasound image is shown below. She is most likely a case of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Complete mole

 

  • In complete mole the characteristic USG picture is as shown and is called as snowstorm appearance
  • In partial mole, the snowstorm appearance is not typically seen; fetal parts will be seen

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Complete Abortion: On ultrasound, an empty uterus is seen
  • Option C: Incomplete abortion: On ultrasound, retained products of conception are seen
  • Option D: Partial mole: On ultrasound, fetal parts may be seen. Typical snowstorm pattern is not seen

Educational Objective: 

The characteristic feature on ultrasound of a complete mole is as shown: SNOWSTORM APPEARANCE

 

Ref: William’s obstetrics, 26th edition, chapter 13,

choices.text: 46XX, of maternal and paternal origin
46XX, of paternal origin only
69XXY, of maternal and paternal origin
69XXY, of paternal origin only

questions.text: A 20 year old woman undergoes suction evacuation for molar pregnancy. Histopathology features are suggestive of complete mole. Regarding karyotype of the tissue, which of the following is most likely:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 46XX of paternal origin only

Complete mole: The molar chromosomes are entirely of paternal origin. They usually have a 46XX karyotype, about 10% have 46XY karyotype.

Other Options: 

  • Option A: 46XX, of maternal and paternal origin: This is wrong as complete mole has only paternal origin
  • Option C: 69XXY, of maternal and paternal origin: This is wrong as complete mole is DIPLOID and is of paternal origin only
  • Option D: 69XXY of paternal origin only: This is wrong as complete mole is DIPLOID

 

Educational Objective: 

  • Partial moles are always TRIPLOD (69XXX/ 69 XXY)
    • 2 sperm fertilize one ova
    • The paternal contribution is called diandry
    • Hence both maternal and paternal component present in partial mole
    • Usually, 69XXX or 69XXY
  • Complete moles are DIPLOID
    • Formed by either 1 sperm fertilizing an empty/ inactivated ova and then undergoes duplication – this is called androgenesis OR 2 sperms (dispermy) fertilize an empty/ inactivated ovum 
    • 46XX or 46XY 
    • Only paternal component; No maternal component

Ref: Berek and Novak, 16th edition, page 2760

choices.text: Decreased
Increased
Unchanged
Can be increased or decreased depending upon complete/ partial mole

questions.text: You are posted in gynaecology ward and sending investigations for a woman with molar pregnancy. Her hCG level is >1,00,000. Her TSH levels are likely to be:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Decreased

  • Hyperthyroidism is observed in 7% patients with complete mole.
  • Elevated free T3, T4 levels and raised TSH is seen in such patients
  • This is because of the similarity betwen hCG and TSH so an increased hCG causes increased production of thyroxine and this causes a negative feedback on TSH.

Educational Objective: 

  • Hyperthyroidism is observed in 7% patients with complete mole.
  • Elevated free T3, T4 levels and raised TSH is seen in such patients
  • This is because of the similarity betwen hCG and TSH so an increased hCG causes increased production of thyroxine and this causes a negative feedback on TSH

Ref: Berek and Novak 16 edition, page 2767
